articles.headline: From Coal to McDonald’s, Catching Up on the Year’s Stories
articles.snippet: Coal companies are facing insolvency, but McDonald’s is working hard to improve its image — and its food.
articles.abstract: Coal companies are facing insolvency, but McDonald’s is working hard to improve its image — and its food.
articles.lead_paragraph: If only there were more lumps of coal in Christmas stockings.

articles.headline: Obscure Corner of Wall St. Draws Skepticism From Investors
articles.snippet: Business development companies are emerging from the shadows as controversy has increased over some of their tactics and results.
articles.abstract: Business development companies are emerging from the shadows as controversy has increased over some of their tactics and results.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most companies listed on American stock exchanges are conventional, familiar businesses like Apple or Exxon Mobil, but the stock market also contains many obscure, even mysterious, specialized sectors that operate with much less public awareness.

articles.headline: Iraqis’ Arrest in Finland Highlights Difficulties in Prosecuting Distant Crimes
articles.snippet: Two refugees have been held in connection with an ISIS massacre near Tikrit, based on a video, but even with such evidence, it’s a challenge to hold suspects accountable for atrocities.
articles.abstract: Two refugees have been held in connection with an ISIS massacre near Tikrit, based on a video, but even with such evidence, it’s a challenge to hold suspects accountable for atrocities.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORSSA, Finland — War in Syria and Iraq seems distant from the incongruously named Villa Eden Care, a glum former hotel now housing some 300 refugees on the edge of this tidy, snow-swept town of 18,000.

articles.headline: In Search of Their Fathers: Seeking Redemption in Vietnam
articles.snippet: Six Americans who lost their fathers in the war met in Ho Chi Minh City with Vietnamese who also lost their parents and found a shared sadness, but no anger.
articles.abstract: Six Americans who lost their fathers in the war met in Ho Chi Minh City with Vietnamese who also lost their parents and found a shared sadness, but no anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — For nearly half a century, Margot Carlson Delogne had grieved over her father’s death. She battled alcoholism, wore a missing-in-action bracelet and deeply resented the Vietnamese who shot down his plane in 1966.

articles.headline: Security Experts and Officials Diverge on ISIS as Hacking Threat
articles.snippet: Officials wonder aloud if public infrastructure could be digitally disabled, but researchers say ISIS is not nearly so sophisticated, or inclined.
articles.abstract: Officials wonder aloud if public infrastructure could be digitally disabled, but researchers say ISIS is not nearly so sophisticated, or inclined.
articles.lead_paragraph: George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, said in a speech last month that Islamic State militants were trying to develop the ability to carry out digital attacks on critical systems, like hospitals, air traffic controls and power plants.

articles.headline: China Plans a New Silk Road, but Trade Partners Are Wary
articles.snippet: Beijing’s effort to revive ancient trade routes is causing geopolitical strains, with countries like Turkey increasingly worried about becoming too dependent on China.
articles.abstract: Beijing’s effort to revive ancient trade routes is causing geopolitical strains, with countries like Turkey increasingly worried about becoming too dependent on China.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — As tensions in the Mideast and Ukraine rose in recent years, Turkey moved to jointly manufacture a sophisticated missile defense system. The $3.4 billion plan would have given Turkey’s military more firepower and laid the foundation to start exporting missiles.

articles.headline: A Silicon Valley for Drones, in North Dakota
articles.snippet: Encouraged by the state, a burgeoning industry in unmanned aircraft draws on local technical expertise and pilots.
articles.abstract: Encouraged by the state, a burgeoning industry in unmanned aircraft draws on local technical expertise and pilots.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — “California and New York want what we’ve got,” said Shawn Muehler, a 30-year-old Fargo resident, gazing at a horizon of empty fields, silos, windbreak trees and hardly any people. A winged craft traces the air, mapping a field with pinpoint accuracy for his start-up, a drone software company called Botlink. “They like drones, but they’ve got a steep learning curve ahead.”

articles.headline: Narendra Modi of India Meets Pakistani Premier in Surprise Visit
articles.snippet: The Indian prime minister Narendra Modi met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif amid tentative steps by both nations to improve their historically tense relations.
articles.abstract: The Indian prime minister Narendra Modi met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif amid tentative steps by both nations to improve their historically tense relations.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It started with a private phone call by the Indian prime minister, Narendra Modi, to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan on Friday morning to wish him a happy birthday.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Salman Masood

articles.headline: How to Help in a Global Refugee Crisis
articles.snippet: A staggering number of people have been displaced, a large portion of them Syrians. Those moved to send financial aid can find some of the best bets here.
articles.abstract: A staggering number of people have been displaced, a large portion of them Syrians. Those moved to send financial aid can find some of the best bets here.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 60 million people around the world were displaced from their homes because of war, conflict or persecution last year, a level not seen since World War II. And Syrian people accounted for roughly 11 million of them.

articles.headline: Parents of Children With Rare Diseases Find Hope in For-Profit Companies
articles.snippet: Businesses allow parents to leverage their wealth, contacts and the hope of investors to jump-start research into the diseases that afflict their children.
articles.abstract: Businesses allow parents to leverage their wealth, contacts and the hope of investors to jump-start research into the diseases that afflict their children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karen Aiach was working as a management consultant when she learned that her first daughter, Ornella, had Sanfilippo syndrome, a rare disease in which a missing enzyme causes toxic substances to build up in the body.
